citeinfo.title: The StreamCat Dataset: Accumulated Attributes for NHDPlusV2 (Version 2.1) Catchments for the Conterminous United States: Dam Density and Storage Volume

pubinfo.publish: US EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory (NHEERL)

descript.abstract:
This dataset represents the dam density and storage volumes within individual, local NHDPlusV2 catchments and upstream, contributing watersheds based on National Inventory of Dams (NID) data. Attributes were calculated for every local NHDPlusV2 catchment and accumulated to provide watershed-level metrics.(See Supplementary Info for Glossary of Terms)
The NID database contains information about the dam’s location, size, purpose, type, last inspection, regulatory facts, and other technical data. Structures on streams reduce the longitudinal and lateral hydrologic connectivity of the system. For example, impoundments above dams slow stream flow, cause deposition of sediment and reduce peak flows. Dams change both the discharge and sediment supply of streams, causing channel incision and bed coarsening downstream. Downstream areas are often sediment deprived, resulting in degradation, i.e., erosion of the stream bed and stream banks. This database was improved upon by locations verified by work from the USGS National Map (Jeff Simley Group). It was observed that some dams, some of them major and which do exist, were not part of the 2009 NID, but were represented in the USGS National Map dataset, and had been in the 2006 NID. Approximately 1,100 such dams were added, based on the USGS National Map lat/long and the 2006 NID attributes (dam height, storage, etc.) Finally, as clean-up, a) about 600 records with duplicate NIDID were removed, and b) about 300 records were removed which represented the same location of the same dam but with a different NIDID, for the largest dams (did visual check of dams with storage above 5000 acre feet and are likely duplicated - about the 10,000 largest dams) (see Data Sources for links to NID data and NHDPlusV2 data).
The (dams/catchment) and (dam_storage/catchment) were summarized and accumulated into watersheds to produce local catchment-level and watershed-level metrics as a point data type (see Data Structure and Attribute Information for a description).
descript.purpose: These data were created in support of the US EPA’s National Aquatic Resource Survey (NARS) and Safe and Sustainable Waters Resources (SSWR) Programs. However, these watershed summaries of landscape data should have broad applicability for hydrological, geomorphic, or ecological modeling, management, and restoration. For details on EPA NARS and SSWR Programs see http://water.epa.gov/type/watersheds/monitoring/aquaticsurvey_index.cfm and http://www.epa.gov/research/progressreport/water.htm
descript.supplinf:
All code and scripts used to produce these data were written in the python or R programming languages and are freely available at ftp://newftp.epa.gov/EPADataCommons/ORD/NHDPlusLandscapeAttributes/StreamCat/Documentation/Code/
Glossary of Terms
Stream Segment: NHDPlusV2 line describing a section of contiguous stream or river between upstream and downstream tributaries (as depicted in USGS topographic quadrangles), except where the segment is a headwater or terminal stream .
Catchment (Cat): The portion of the landscape where surface flow drains directly to an NHDPlusV2 stream segment, excluding any upstream contributions.
Watershed (Ws): The set of hydrologically-connected catchments, consisting of all upstream catchments that contribute flow to any local catchment.
COMID: Unique identifier for each stream segment, and associated catchment, in NHDPlusV2. Watershed metrics describe entire area of all catchments that accumulate to the specific catchment based on the NHD PlusFlow table.
Riparian Buffer (RipBuf): Spatial buffer of 100-m that was added to NHDPlusV2 stream network and NLCD water pixels. The buffers were used to spatially constrain calculations for some landscape metrics to within 100 meters of the riparian area.
Landscape Layer: Any geospatial layer from which we derived statistical summaries for both local catchments and watersheds. These landscape layers were comprised of several GIS formats, including vector (points, lines, or polygons) and raster.

idinfo.useconst: None. procstep.procdesc: Dataset downloaded from ftp://ftpext.usgs.gov/pub/er/va/reston/NAWQA_ENS/GIS_DATA/dams/ Data source, date, units and resolution were recorded in a project tracking spreadsheet and verified.
Projection of dataset verified as USGS Albers Equal Area Conic and projected if necessary

Performed a visual inspection of dataset for gaps, edges other anomalous features. Verified how no-data values were represented and recoded values as no-data where appropriate (for instance, if no-data locations represented by 0's or -9999, these were converted to no-data values).
Isolate catchments that exist on US border and clip them to the areas that exist within the US to calculate the percent full for these catchments.

Ran zonal statistics python script (StreamCat.py) to calculate zonal statistics for all NHDPlusV2 catchments in each NHDPlusV2 Vector Processing Unit (VPU). Zonal statistics were perofrmed using either ZonalStatisticsAsTable, TabulateArea, or spatially joining vector point data to catchments. Each method applies to the type of landscape layer being evaluated, Continuous, Categorical, or Point. We also calculated the percent of each catchment that had coverage by a given landscape layer (i.e. was not null). These results are accumulated using the NHDPlusV2 flow table to summarize upstream catchment values and complete watershed values for the metric.

Clean and standardize results of zonal statistics table from accumulation script / process (makeFinalTables.py). Clean up consisted of calculating mean value of metric per zone, renaming and sorting zonal statistics fields, and writing zonal results to .csv file.

citeinfo.origin: United States Geological Survey (USGS) and US EPA
citeinfo.title: National Hydrography Dataset Plus

enttyp.enttypd: Statistics of dams existing in each local catchment (Cat) and accumulated watershed (Ws).

attr.attrdef: Unique ID label to each catchment in NHDPlusV2
Area of the catchment measured in square kilometers.
% of the catchment that is covered by the landscape layer.
Area of the local catchment and accumulated upstream catchments composing the entire watershed (Ws) measured in square kilometers.
% of the watershed that is covered by the landscape raster.
Density of georeferenced dams within the local catchment. (dams/AreaSqKm) (Cat)
Mean normal storage volume of all dam reservoirs (NORM_STORA in NID) within the local catchment. (Cat) (cubic meters/square kilometer)
Mean NID storage volume of all dam reservoirs (NID_STORA in NID) within the local catchment. (Cat) (cubic meters/square kilometer)
Density of georeferenced dams within the total upstream watershed. (dams/AreaSqKm)(Ws)
Mean normal storage volume of all dam reservoirs (NORM_STORA in NID) within the total upstream watershed. (Ws) (cubic meters/square kilometer)
Mean NID storage volume of all dam reservoirs (NID_STORA in NID) within the total upstream watershed. (Ws) (cubic meters/square kilometer)
